column11: Review Text

outrageous...toilet only for tourists.  I am a Sri Lankan but a tourist. had paid tourist price. I wasn't allowed to use this toilet.  Why... I don't know anything like this in Sri Lanka.  I was treated here as a second class.  Never again...

column8: A great intro to the ancient ruins.
column11: You kinda have to go here to purchase your tickets to visit the ruins so its sort of part of the package. If you have becer heard of Polonaurwa and the second Ancient City, this museum will bring you up to speed before you exit to commence your trip. I felt it was worth it. You can also find several eager tour guides outside to take you on your trip to the ruins site

column8: Preparatory to the visit to the excavations
column11: The ticket office for the excavations of the ancient city of Polonnaruwa corresponds to that of the Archaeological Museum and the ticket includes the two visits. The cost for foreigners is 30 USDollar, without any kind of discount. If you can swallow and pay the amount, a tour of the museum is interesting. Don't hold high expectations: it's a museum with some slightly more modern parts but most of the display isn't very eye-catching. But if you have the patience and time to read some explanations, your visit will also be better and more conscious. Sometimes the guardians spend a few words of explanation out of kindness (or perhaps because they expect a tip?). Outside the Museum you will be engulfed by many guides who will offer to accompany you both to the museum and to the excavations. It may be worth it for the latter (for us it was a boon: we saved a lot of time in the huge archaeological site and acted as an interpreter in a misadventure we had that day), but not for the museum: if you want to save a little something, visit it yourself.

column8: The start point for your Polonnaruwa hitorical sigh tour
column11: The museum is not as interesting as seeing the historical sights themselves, but it's definitely necessary to understand what you will actually visit at what location and what you will actually see. At the same time, this is a ticket office where you need to buy a ticket to enter different museum locations. As with anything at Sri Lanka, tourists and locals get very different prices for entrance tickets.

column8: Rude and unhelpful staff let things down here.
column11: The staff are very rude and unhelpful here. They pressure you to buy tickets even for people who don't want to go. They followed us to the car for some reason to check who was in the car. Its all very strange. Rude and unhelpful staff let things down here.

column8: A small but beautiful museum in Pulanaruva, Sri Lanka.
column11: Located in natural settings surrounded by ponds brimming with water lilies, the archaeological museum of Pulanaruva needs atleast two hours to see the various artifacts discovered during archaeological excavations in and around Pulanaruva, Sri Lanka. The artifacts/ remains of both the victors and the vanquished are displayed in various sections of the museum. The museum is air-conditioned with a quiet ambience. The visitors, though few, comprise both domestic and international tourists. The entry fee is quite reasonable and the staff are friendly. A visitors book is also available for your comments. Enroute to Pulanaruva we also saw a few wild elephants. For unknown reasons, photography inside the museum is not allowed. Worth visiting.

column8: Learned a lot about ancient irrigation systems in Sri Lanka
column11: Must visit place in Polonaruwa Sri Lanka. Can learn a lot about ancient technology, irrigation systems & engineering work during ancient Ceylon.

It is hard to miss this museum where is located right after the ticketing counter of Polonnaruwa Ancient Site. Worth to check it out which provides a good overviews and narrations of the architecture and structures of the ancient world at Polonnaruwa. A short visit of 30 mins to have some basic understanding would make the visit to the heritage sites more meaningful.
Shame you are not aloud to make any pictures there are some interesting objects in display well worth it to  see and explore
Came here only because it was included in the ticket. Information about the site is very nice but I preferred to actually see the sites itself

Some nice exponation pieces but very little information. Why number the pieces if there are no explanations as to what the numbers are? Why put several pieces together with the mere description „hindu ritual utensils“ without any further information on how or what for they were used? Please put some effort into proper curation of the museum!

While you cannot take photographs, the museum does give you some perspective of the site. Some pieces of note included a bronze chest, ancient hospital tools and statues of Siva Nataraja and the amply breasted Sivakamasundari. The layout is quality over quantity. It can readily be visited in under an hour.
Has done nice artefacts and gives an understanding of the site.  So much more could be done with a couple of films and a bit of computer graphic work. An opportunity waiting to be taken
We had a thorough look at the place. Its treasures are amazing...great context to imbibe before you go through the place.

The museum gives a quick introduction of what to expect from the Polonnaruwa archaeological site. It mainly showcases the 3 great kings of Sri Lanka, and the civilisation, education and religion that they brought to the people. Unfortunately you can’t take pictures inside the museum.
The museum has some interesting facts to give you a background into the history before you set off. Not the most interesting museum I’ve visited.

Near the place where you purchase tickets for the whole City. There are many tout guides at the doorway and once you leave. You are also not allowed to take any photo even if for the writeups to read more on. The place is not recommended for the lacklustre service and respect for visitors.

A must go if you have visit the ruins. Although small, the artefacts were well maintained and displays well curated, especially the temple and palace ruins. A pity no photos allowed. Highly recommended.

Great place to get a wholistic view of The Polonnaruwa era, its key landmarks and replicas of same along with historical artifacts. It’s a clean place with detail descriptions and assistants around who will explain about the items in detail. It’s in a very comfortable air-conditioned environment. It has good washroom facilities as well. Ample parking.

Buy your tickets and walk on through, rude staff and they follow you around to ensure you arent taking photos of their photos... Of the things you just paid to go see. Spend more effort informing visitors and less effort looking down on tourists keeping the place open.

My wife and myself are currently holidaying in Sri Lanka and earlier today visited Polonnaruwa and started our visit at the Archaeological Museum. This is easy to find and not particularly cheap - US30 & US$15 for foreign adult and children respectively although this One Day Pass does permit entry to both the main site and the Gal Vihara. There is plenty to see although many of the artefacts and photos appear to have been in the same display areas/cases for many years. It is also forbidden to take photos in most of the inside of the museum - primarily, in the hope that you will purchase photos of any particular exhibits at the end of your visit. All in all, a good way to start your day in Polonnaruwa and - bearing in mind that barely 5% of the old Capital/City has been excavated - there is indeed plenty to see!!

This museum is very good. One good advice is to visit it before visiting all the sites present in Polonnaruwa. This because you will earn something more about the site in general which you can explore later.

It's a great archeological site, there's not much to actually see inside the museum itself. Go and explore the temples and ruins outside, it's a big area and might take quite some time. Get ready to pay 5000 rupees, which is like 1/4 - 1/5 of average Sri Lankan salary, and yes, locals pay hundred times less. Although in US dollars it's not that much like $20 - 25, and you can afford it, but it's the only country which charges tourists HUNDRED times more for entrance. That isn't nice at all.

This would be the best of our museams .Excellent lay out makes one not be overawed by the exhibits.Descriptions are apt and brief .Ideally the museam should be the last place to be in the ancient city tour.
very interesting museum,in Polonnaruwa.stone creatins are there,nice outside view with the near by water tank,we visited the place last year,very interesting
Mainly before-after pictures and a few models, The original items are worth it but don't plan for too much time in here. The aircon isn't working so it's like a sauna, too.
You can see some statues and old pics there but you cant take photo there. At first i did not know i must not take a pic so i just have one picture from this place. But it is not worth go there.
I would recommend looking round the museum first as it has models of the original buildings. Information is displayed in English also.

Nice museum, texts also in English. Very nice scale models of some of the buildings so you can see the roof that once covered the dagobas and buildings. Now only the pillars remain. Also very nice bronze statues of Hindu gods.

We went here before taking in the archaeological site. It is full of artifacts, probably replicas and plenty of conjecture over what some of the archaeological would have looked like if they were still standing. Make sure to grab a map of the World Heritage Site to help guide you through from the front counter. You are not allowed to take photographs from inside the museum.

We visited here after the site, which is the wrong way around. The scale reconstruction model shows the former grandeur of this splendid site. The exhibits are certainly worth a look, but be brief and explore the main site which is where the treasure is really.

A great little museum to start your tour of the ruins, the building and the display furniture is simple - but the information is comprehensive and gives you a good context for your trip to the ruins, especially the pictures showing the state of the site before its reconstruction and the beautiful bronze statues and figures from the site :)

Although we had a driver guide for our Sri Lanka tour, we had a local guide here who was a specialist in Polonnaruwa. He was most enthusiastic on ensuring we got the most from our visit, which began with him showing us the huge layout of the ancient site from the model inside the museum; which although small has some truly beautiful artefacts. The model layout together with our guides' description put us in good stead for our visit to the actual sites later on. The museum is nicely set out and there's good information in English. The wonderful bronzes of gods, particularly Ganesha and his parents Shiva and Parvati, are very memorable. Sadly no photography is allowed in the museum.

The service at the reception is very bad, the women were overcharging. I live in Sri Lanka and I have a resident card. As such, I always pay as a national but in that place, for the first time, they refused to consider my resident card and wanted to receive the full money, I don't know why. They were rude and not supportive.

Unfortunately our tuk tuk driver didn't know the area very well and on arriving at the museum there were numerous guides offering their services but after the $26 per head entrance fee we were loathed to pay more.  We then were completely lost as to where to go - there was no signage at all and no map offered.  We were told by the guide to go and see the museum first and it was interesting but should then lead you out to the ruins behind.  Consequently we walked around the car park lost, trying to find an entrance and then followed others with a guide.  After that our driver took us round to the main site on the other side of the road.  People were hawking bike hire but to be honest if you have a tuk tuk / car then just drive to each site, walk around and then go to next..  The area is extensive and I would not recommend trying to walk it in the heat.  It is visually very pretty and the few boards around the site seemed to keep repeating themselves.  Most people just read from their guide books like us!  It would be a great help if by the museum entrance / exit there were maps to show you where to go. Sorry, I am talking about all the ruins and the site in general which will take anything from 2 hours to all day depending on how thorough you are.  The museum itself is 30 minutes tops.

The ticket for Polonnaruwa are sold here inside the Museum Building.  Photography of any kind is prohibited inside the museum.  Some visitors opt to pay a "guide" to walk with them and provide explanations of items on display inside the museum and to accompany them inside the Polonnaruwa complex. It can be a bit warm inside the museum.  Restrooms and a small gift shop is situated at the far end of the building.

Buy your tickets at the  museum for the whole area.  Good to visit museum first to get an idea what you will be seeing.  Some say prices are high, but for 2 -3 hours of wandering around these sites we thought it reasonable.  Museum has good exhibits and models of what ruins used to be like.
Buy your tickets here, as they will be checked several times while you visit all the ruins. Current price is $25 (at a current exchange rate in rupees) for foreigners.
A small museum with some very nice sculptures. Some background on the ruins at the arscheological site.

Tickets to visit Pollonaruwa are sold here. This museum is interesting to get a quick overview of what you're about to see. Also some beautiful Hindu statues. There are very detailed explanations about each ruin, we skipped over those though.

Located outside the archeological park and near the ticket counter, the small museum would give you a feeling of the history of the place you're going to visit, an idea of the splendor that must have been the capital of the second oldest kingdom of the country, the Kindom of Polonnaruwa.

The Museum is located near the Heritage Site Entry Ticket counter and can be visited prior visiting the Archaeological Sites. It is a small Museum, basically displaying Artifacts connected with ancient capital located at Polonnaruwa. The Artifacts are well displayed, especially the miniature models of building, which are currently in ruins at Polonnaruwa.
...to first go and see the museum before you visit the outside temples and built structures - lots of information, best with a guide

We started of here at the museum and bought all the entry tickets to all the sites for 18000 family of five and another 3000 for a private guide . The museum should be the first start of the tour as there are the replicas of the original ruins and a great way to then visit the rest of the sites.
This was our introduction to the local area. Worth taking the time to have a look and appreciated the local area.

We visited here before going to the ruins and work h a quick walk through visit as the miniature scale models help you visualise what you see later. A one way walk through operation seems to be in place which is good. Watch out for all the locals desperate to sell their tourist goods. The nearer you get to the end the lower price you can barter. As you leave the museum look out for locals in the river fishing. This was really interesting to watch.

Although the ancient city is ruined one can assume the Majestic nature of the city by seeing the reconstructions in their miniature forms within this museum. A must visit before you visit the actual ruins. They are so small admission fee but it's worth paying. They provide free brochure for all visitors. Available in English language also.

Perhaps not as well displayed by world standards and some of the hefty fee to visit this ancient site could well be used for updating this museum. Nevertheless it is still fairly well set out and a 'must visit' as it does give a good impression and overview of the history of Polonnaruwa before you set out to explore the many ruins at this sacred site.
Although compared to aussiemuseum standards this museum is somewhat innocent there are some interesting exhibits to view and some interesting things to learn. Glad we went.

Probably best to see this before you go to the ruins but we were keen to get to the ruins early before it got too hot. Some lovely pieces and lots of information about the site and what it would have looked like

The web site link mentioned here is not working (as at 2/7/2018) please correct This place is a must see and with a little entrance fee . You are not allowed to touch these ruins and talk to officials if you need further clarifications . I donot recommend to take photos with flashes

We visited this museum in June as part of a group tour through Trip A Deal. Our guide, Lakmal, lead us through the museum explaining all the history of a lot of the objects. Like many other sites in Sri lanka, this museum was so interesting. You really need a guide to explain everything to you. Without one, we would have missed so much. Well worth the visit.
Enjoyed going to this museum. Has a great time line of the story of Polonnaruwa the ancient capital of Sri Lanka.

Sorry, they need the museum, but to us we strongly preferred getting out and seeing the actual ruins. It good to get an overview but it could have effectively been done in a quarter of the space and time
This is located the where you have to buy tickets for entrance and its include the price of ticket. Many things to see and brief descriptions. Do not miss it

We were only going to buy our tickets here and then head out but went through the museum at the advice of our driver. We were very happy we did. The museum does a good job of giving you the context of the ancient ruins, and, even better, allows you see scale replicas of the buildings. I found this incredibly helpful, especially in cases like the monk's hospital and the palace buildings, many of which just have foundation stones left. Even for buildings where there are walls still standing (like the main palace), seeing the replica will give you a nice reference point for how large the building would have been. Between the museum and our guidebook, we did not feel we needed a guide for the ruins. Best of all, the price is included in your admission. Don't skip it!

Visited here prior to going around the ancient city.  This helped to put yhe whole civilisation into perspective and lay a good foundation and understanding of the history of the whole site. Worth doing
after purchasing your ticket, please go through this museum to learn more about the places before going out, it will help you to understand more.

This is the museum at the entrance to the site (where you pay) and it is worth a stroll thru it as it gives you and idea of the layout of Pollonaruwa and the mini scale reproductions of the buildings gives you a feel of how grand this place was int its heyday! There are lots of statues and artifacts in the museum and really it is well laid out. Worth 30 mins or so!

The museum is where you buy your ticket to access the archeological sites. It gives a good summary of the history and also houses some of the artefacts. We managed it in about 30mins. Can be done in less. Toilets on site. No wifi.

There was a great deal to see here and it was well laid out. However one had to buy a guide to be able to identify the exhibits as there were few labels otherwise. It would take a much longer time to view this museum properly but it left us with a good impression of the contents of the grounds to visit. The shop was good and prices very moderate.

This is a well laid out modern museum with several of the artefacts found on the main site.  It has models depicting how several of the buildings must have looked and bought the whole sit to life.  We visited after visiting the main site, which suited us.

Located near to the Deepa Uyana, this museum carries vast history of the ancient Pulathisipura. However you can’t photograph inside of the museum but you can obtain photos of the relevant attraction from the museum office Opens 9-6

The archaeological museum of polonnaruwa is the first stop in the polonnaruwa archaeological ruins district, because it's where the ticket office is. Contains alot of photos and alot artefacts found from archaeological ruins of polonnaruwa and suburbs. No photos allowed inside the museum. 1hour is enough if you want to go through it. Toilets and souvenir shop facilities available inside the museum. Rite next to the museum is the king nissankamallas palace complex

Reading about the Archaeological site and ia bit of it's history before you go is a very good idea and a great way to enhance the experience of the visit.  The Museum is also a great place, however, like Horton Plains (another government run site) some of the staff use their position as a chance to short change tourists and respond as if they are insulted when they are caught. Go to Polonnaruwa and sink yourself into a bit of it's fantastic history.

and get a guide book shop at the end next to washroom , no admission fee Then you have a good idea of the ancient city and can enjoy a bike tour You can get to the shop and washroom (such at Sigiryia) without ticket Same advice there If you could visit the museum before the visit that ideal, but the ideal is also to be in the park at the coolest hours early morning to help you thru the ruins No pictures inside!

We went to quite a few museums in Sri Lanka, and this was my favorite.  It seems quite new and clean (compared to Anuradhapura, which was a bit of a dump), and the items in here are really nice.  It doesn't overwhelm, you can go through it in 1/2 hour and get a sense of what you are about to see.  Don't miss it!
The collection of artifacts from numerous sites in Polonnaruwa is a well assembled collection of the most important and best objects found.

The museum is a must visit (specially if you intend to not take a guide) for someone to know more about the Polonnaruwa ruins. It set the right perspective about the ruins before you start seeing them.
A small museum, it does not add much to your knowledge (if you are in the possession of a travel guide book like Lonely Planet).  You buy your tickets for the ruins here, so hard to miss the museum.

It didn't help that there were hundreds of school students there but you have to buy the archaeological zone tickets here, so you may as well pass through the museum.  It's not as well organised as the one at Sigiriya so I don't think it tells the history very well and is mostly just random photos, although it has a few dioramas of the key buildings and some statues.

The museam is not very big, so you have time to have a read and undesrtand a bit the history of the city before visiting. It also has models of the palaces and a 3D map of all the important places to visit

If you are interested in sri lankan history, this is a best place to start to understand the ruins before visiting them.  just like most of the sites in Sri lanka, this too has entrance fees of 7500 LKR for foreign tourist and 2000 LKR for SAARC national and ask several times if you want a SAARC discount and be persistent.

If you are planing to visit Polonnaruwa archaeological site, you must visit this museum. The model of the archaeological site at the entrance helps to plan your places to visit. And the you'll be able to view statues up close.

I started my journey through the Polonnaruwa Ancient Ruins with a visit to the Archaeological Museum.  Would highly recommend that the museum is visited first.  It enables you to put into perspective what the ruins would have looked like, and their purposes back in their peak.  My guide for the ruins also took me through the museum, he used to work as an archaeologist so I was blessed with phenomenal insight and knowledge. Would visit again and recommend to others.
A must if you come here.A new museum.This is well designed. The lake nearby makes  a pretty setting.The history of the area is well depicted.

It is best to spend time here -  a lot of time. This will help you relive every part of the ancient ruins and palaces of Polonnaruwa. Our group wanted to go to the sites first but if you dont read about the history and research glory of the places cant be enjoyed in full. Ensure to spend time here before exploring the palaces.

You can learn some History of Sri Lanka by visiting the archaeological museum at Pollonaruwa.   Entrance fee is $25 ($12.50 for children) including the visits to the citadel. SAARC member countries get a discount if you would show  your passport and you get a 50% discount on the entry fee. (Like Sigriya) This is a great place to start a trip to Polonnaruwa, particularly as its models of the city’s buildings allow visitors to figure just about the ruins to be seen. It is located close to the Prakkrama Samudraya (meaning the sea which is made from joining of 3 Tanks), this museum is a must watch if you are interested about the Polonnaruwa history. Archaeological museum in Polonnaruwa is where the traveler should start his exploration before visiting the conserved historical sites. It gives you so much of information which helps to appreciate what you see later on in the ruined city. There are many models of the key. This is the best place to get information on history of Polonnaruwa  and is recommended for both locals and foreigners. You have to go to the museum to buy entrance tickets to the site. It is worth spending some time looking at the exhibits as they have models of what the ruins must have looked like in their heyday. The beautiful museum which houses an amazing bronze of Nataraja, and Parvati (in Tara Style) - Don't ever miss it. The Polonnaruwa Archaeological Museum exhibits finds excavated from the medieval city of Polonnaruwa, a UNESCO-listed site.  Interesting stone boxes with offerings. Dancing Shiva Nataraja in bronze. Really worth the visit (better before the ruins) It is an extremely  informative museum despite its humble Outlook and gives you some impressions about Polonnaruwa as former capital. The exhibits are categorized and presented, and the remodeled items are very interesting too. We got impressed by the models of how the ruins originally looked before the fires. A great idea is that it brought to life the ruins once you actually saw them. We learned many things from here. There were many historical things on display. Stone sculptures of Hindu deities, Buddhas and Bodhisattva and fragments of columns were on display. The museum is very well organised: it displays archaeological remains recovered from the site as well as scale models of the citadel's buildings; it also provides detailed information about the artifacts displayed as well as on the history of the citadel and its surroundings. We got a very interesting guided tour (free) led by an archaeologist. On the first room, a large model of the city and ruins gives an idea of how enormous the kingdom was.  Many photos of the monuments  were shown before and after restoration. It and around an hour is enough for visit. It has few rooms that dedicates to different topics. Each room has very good selections of exhibits with titles in English. We enjoyed a lot models of former capital and its buildings. It helped us to imagine them when we saw ruins. Museum has small shop with interesting selections of the  books of interest. We are really glad that we visited museum. It's really worth an hour of our visit. I recommend you to visit Archaeological Museum of Polonnaruwa.

The museum is a detailed citation of all there is to see in Pollunnaruwa archeological site. It has detailed models of the complexes with history and excavated articles. It helped me decide which places to visit since I wasn’t sure of seeing it all. Not very big, it’s just about the correct information needed to orient one to the ruins. Restrooms are clean and the lake nearby is good to hang by.

Thankg God price was included in the VERY EXPENSIVE package to visit ruins+museum.. !!! ruins were just ok.. museum was a total NO WAY ! i almost fell asleep ! if you want to see Polonnaruwa ruins you must buy there in the museum the ticket ...price is " CRAZY " for sri lanka standards and it's expensive for italian standards : 21 euro or 25 dollars !!
The archaeological museum is rather small and the collection reflects the history of the ruins. It is not extensive nor impressive but worth a visit as it is part of the cost of the entry ticket
Small and uncluttered with some very nice bronzes down the back. Restrooms available before you embark on activities around the old city.

This was a really cool place to visit. I hired a guide outside of the entrance for 1000 rupees. He was very informative and took us around to a few places. We rented bikes from our hotel and were able to visit most sites. The sites are much closer together as compared to the sites in Anuradhapura. The entrance ticket covers three different places: Archeological Museum, Lankathilaka Image House, and Gal Vihara (I recommend doing them in this order). The price: 3350 rupees per person. Buy tickets at the museum. Visit the museum and give it a decent look over as it will explain a lot of what you see later at different sites (especially if you don't want to hire a guide).
Polonnaruwa is within the mid country cultural triangle. This is one of the many sites providing information & ancient statues and artefacts of ancient civilisation. Well worth a visit.

After spending a couple hours cooling off for avoid heat stroke after a long day biking around the ruins, I tried going to the museum on my own around 5:25 pm. Guidebook had said it would close at 6pm.  Doors were closed, staff reluctantly let me in when I swore I'd be fast and begged. Ran through in 5min. No photos allowed anyhow. Had nice displays and explanations. Not too large. Wish I had had 30-40min to spend in there at my leisure.
A quick visit to the museum is worthwhile before hitting the temples. A particular highlight was seeing the models of what the temples would have looked like with their wooden roofs on.

Its not a huge museum, just a small one. It will take maximum half an hour to have a stroll inside the museum. The entry fee is altogether with the polonnaruwa entry fee, so won't cost you extra. Just to have a quick summary of the whole Sri Lankan history, its a very good place.

The museum is probably one of the better ones linked to the main sites, but probably missing some information that would make it a 5. Again I wonder how much of the entrance fee is reinvested into the site. Worth 30 minutes of your time either at the start or end of the site tour, we did it at the end and added some value to the day.

You start the visit of the Polonnaruwa site with the museum as the office desk and the entrance tickets are sold here. Nice small museum with a large overview of the different findings like statues, coins, ceramics, little braze items, boeddha's. Note: they even have a museum shop at the end, but it smells like hell!

30 mins spent here prior to touring the site is well worth it. You get lots of background info but importantly there are some models which give you a god idea what the buildings would have looked like

We popped into the museum for 20 minutes after purchasing our tickets. It is a good introduction to the site, but not necessary to spend too much time there. Definitely use your time enjoying the actual ruins. There are info cards at each area of the ruins that you can read.

The ruins themselves are a fantastic experience. However, this museum is feted as being "probably the best museum in Sri Lanka". If this is the country's museum, Sri Lanka needs to up its museum game.

Well worth an hour of ones time if visiting the ancient city of Polonnaruwa. Beds visit before seeing the monuments as the museum gives an excellent chronological history of the site and Sri Lanka in general.
The  Museum gives and idea of the grandeur of the buildings that are ruined today - many good models are on display.
To be honest didn't like it, it's a poor museum and it looks like no one puts an effort to make it better.

If you are heading to the polonnaruwa area to look at the ruins, the museum gives you a good overview of what they were like and what they were to cover. We went before we went to look at the ruins, which was good for an overview, but I think in some ways it would have made sense to go after to understand what you have seen.  Either way, it was worthwhile going and having a look to get a better understanding.  Signs in English as well as other languages, along with other pieces which would have been in the area.

Some museums in SL are nothing more than collections of not much. This is a true museum.  There are great historical relics.  There were also great models helping you understand how the area looked and was constructed in the day.

Our tour of the ruins at Polonnaruwa began at the Archaeological Museum. This is a well-organized exhibit of items found in the ancient city plus wonderful models of what some of the buildings looked like originally. Our guide was thorough in explaining what we were seeing not only in the museum but also throughout the region as we walked through the ruins. We were pleased that we were taken through the museum before taking the tour of the ruins. This gave us a better understanding of what we were seeing.
Visit the museum before you visit the archaeological ruins of Polonnaruwa. Beautiful statues and artifacts

Worth visiting and getting the guides explanation about the area before going to visit the sites. The importance of the area comes alive when visiting the museum. There are many beautiful artifacts here. And a last bathroom break before heading into the park and wandering the various sites.

Foreign visitors buy their entry tickets at the museum and it gives a bit of introduction to the archaeological ruins.  Suggest not spending a huge amount of time here, as the displays are generally quite average.  But they do help you identify the sights within the archaeological park that you may want to prioritize.

This was an interesting place to see - the artefacts and materials on display gave a little insight into some of the activities and life of the times of the people back then. More info is needed to fill in the gaps, though.
The place where you also get your ticket, gives you a good idea of what you will see inside the archaeological site.

Spent 30 minutes or so going through here (shop at the end has good/cheap guides to this and other SL highlights) but it was lacking some interactivity. Even with a good guide giving background info I'm afraid I 'lost it' a bit in here. Our old group very grateful for the toilets though, which are at the FAR end of the building by the shop.

I was really impressed with this museum probably the best one I'd seen in Sri Lanka. Many many interesting artefacts, a lot of culture and history. Pleasant cool building to walk around and well laid out

The museum is really worthwhile visiting before you visit the site. It details the history of the last hundreds of years with what happened over the various kings reigns. The antiquities inside are fantastic quality and very well presented and preserved. There are also several models of how the sites were allowing you to appreciate the magnitude of it all. Highly with while.

The museum next to the lake (reervoir) is where you buy your 25$ (3750LRK) admission ticket for the main archeological site in Polonnaruwa. It is a very good introduction to begin your visit. Among the usual artifacts, statues etc. one expects of the site they also have a topographical model of the whole site with miniatures of what the buildings once looked like. So certainly best to do before visiting the actual site.

The museum presents useful information but tends to be very repetitive and not the best organized. It's worth a brief visit to understand the history and ruins of Polonnaruwa, but spend most of your time at the actual sites.

This is absolutely worth a visit, either as an introduction before you visit the actual site, or for recapitulation when you have already been there. Both the exhibitions and the historical and scientific information content are well above what I have learned to expect from small museums like this. Lots of interesting objects on display as well as detailed reconstruction models of some of the buildings and well laid out overviews of the site from different time periods. This is also where you buy tickets to the Archaeological site itself.

I watched documentary about the history of polonnaruwa . Brochure was only in local language. you get three tickets one for museum, other two are for the site. You can get a bike. I had a taxi which took me around. It is informative and important to see before you see the ruins of the kingdom.
We enjoyed a leisurely stroll through the museum. Plenty of history and artefacts to see do not miss the short film in the entrance

It is important to visit the museum before visiting the actual site, the Polonnaruwa heritage site The museum offers a short summary of the art and history of this site. Many rare statues of Indian Gods and Goddesses are kept here.

This is not a large museum but it was well presented and interesting as was the entire area   of Polonnaruwa. Visit the museum but spend most of the time available out amongst the many historical sites around the area which was very good and interesting.
Museum was good as it gave me information about this place. Much historical pieces preserve in the museum. My guide showed me the lay out of the entire place which was located inside the museum.
An excellent museum to compliment your visit to the archaeological site. Has reconstructions of what the city once looked like, together with some amazing bronze statuettes that have been recovered.
Needs time and guide for better understanding. We got a nice old guide Prem who explained every thing very well. If Indian carry your passport for 50 % discount
The best place to get information on history of Polonnaruwa and it's worth visiting. Recommended for both locals and foreigners.
You have to go to the museum to buy entrance tickets to the site. It is worth spending some time looking at the exhibits as they have models of whet the ruins must have looked like in their heyday.

A beautiful museum which houses an amazing bronze of Nataraja, and Parvati (in Tara Style) - Dont ever miss it. If you are from SAARC nation, show your passport and you get a 50% discount on the entry fee. (Like Sigriya)

History ....(need to pay) but it's worth .... The Polonnaruwa Archaeological Museum exhibits finds excavated from the medieval city of Polonnaruwa, a UNESCO-listed site. This is a great place to start a trip to Polonnaruwa, particularly as its models of the city’s buildings allow visitors to see what they would have looked like. Moving through the museum, visitors can learn about this former capital by theme and the highlights include a series of Chola bronzes. A vast network of National Museums and Archeological museums maintained by the government are scattered across the country and provides a fascinating glimpse into Sri Lanka’s deep rooted cultural heritage, natural history, and traditional folklore.
Good place to start before going to visit the ruins. Guide is mandatory to explain all the stuff. From here we can start the journey to visit other historical places .
Good description of the history of Polonnaruwa. There are some models which help visualise what the buildings would have been like at the time.

This museum was OK.  but that's all.  Just OK.  There were definitely some cool artifacts but I got the idea that some of the things on display were fake.  I am no expert but some items just didn't add up.  There were also hundreds of numbered pictures on the walls that had no descriptions to explain what there were.  Even some of the physical displays of artifacts had no explanations with them. The personnel there are very adamant about no picture taking because the museum wants to make money off you through forcing you to buy photos from the gift shop if you want photos of the displays.  Problem was, the photo rack had about 8 photos in it for purchase and didn't seem to have been restocked for some time.  This was a frustrating rip off. I would not have even gone through the museum under normal circumstances because I would have hired a local guide.  Trouble is, the tourism ministry in Sri Lanka mandated that prices between foreign tourists and locals be extremely offset.  I think locals paid less than 50 (fifty) rupees to enter while I had to pay 5,500 (five thousand five hundred), which amounts to USD 35.  That sapped my budget for a local guide, effectively taking money out of the local market.  It was this way at all the national monuments in that tourists payed outrageously more than locals.  I am all for charging more for foreign tourists because foreign wages are much better than local wages, but come on.  I was unable to help out a local guide because I had to give the museum ticket office all my money.  The ticket included entrance to the museum and all the sites.

The place looks modest and unpretentious. But it is so rich in content. The museum is a mine of information, effectively laid-out. Contrary to many views, I found that visiting the museum AFTER the Polonnaruwa ruins was particularly enriching. It allows to better relate to, and appreciate, what we had just seen. And also to take shelter from the hot afternoon sun! However, the ventilation/ cooling in the premises wasn't functioning too well when we visited and it was quite stuffy inside; hopefully this was just a once-off occurrence that day and not the everyday norm.

Archaeological museum in Polonnaruwa is where the traveller should start his exploration before visiting the conserved historical sites. It gives you so much of information which helps to appreciate what you see later on in the ruined city. There are many models of the key structures re-created to give an idea how the structures would have looked like during the grand old day. It is a well displayed museum.

Extremely informative museum despite it's humble Outlook. A good introduction to the ancient city before visiting the different ruins themselves. The exhibits are categorized and presented, and the remodeled works are very interesting too!

Impressed by the models of how the ruins originally looked before the fires. A great idea as it brought to life the ruins once you actually saw them. $25 ($12.50 for children) does seem a lot but this is a day out for the whole family and much of the money goes towards more excavations as only 20% has been excavated. Y UNESCO to date. Now it is up to the Sri Lankan government to reclaim & excavate the remaining ruins in the jungle. An exciting project. Take water & socks for when you visit inside the shrines as the soil/rocks can be very hot
The Museum gives all what you want to know  and then after you go to the site , you will see the real one
the most interesting part is the 3D models of the buildings as they would have looked 1,000 years ago. Don't plan to spend more than 15 min in it,
I went here few months ago to learn some History of Sri Lanka. This was a great place. I learned many things from here. There were many historical things.
Not only will you have a better overview of the immense ruins but also clean facilities before you start your trek.
The museum gave us a very good overview of the whole site and the different occupants. Without this I would have found it difficult to understand what I was seeing amongst the ruins.
Sets the whole site in context. Would be nothing without the site but equally the site would be of much less interest without the museum.
A very interesting museum. We visited after visiting the ruins. It has some artifacts from the sites. It has some very interesting pictures of some of the ruins before and after restoration work.
Four of us on tour visited here first and found it very interesting. Although made more sense once you visited sites. Well laid out and good set up.
Avoid visiting on a hot day, there is no proper AC. Get the combined ticket so that you can visit all closeby sites, cheaper. Have water with you.

Entrance is included in the ticket's price of the citadel ($ 25.00 pp). The museum is very well organised: it displays archaeological remains recovered from the site as well as scale models of the citadel's buildings; it also provides detailed information about the artefacts displayed as well as on the history of the citadel and its surroundings. Recommended to visit before visiting the citadel!!

Polonnaruwa was Sri Lankan capital from the 11th to the 13th centuries. It was considered safer than Anuradhapura because it was further inland. The remains of temples, bath houses and monastries are scattered around a large area adjacent to Lake Wewa. The archeological museum has a separate room dedicated to one theme - viz. citadel, outer city, monastry area . There is a model of the Royal Palace which was once 7 storeys high.

Excellent museum located in Polonnaruwa city centre, near the lake. Entrance is included in Polonnaruwa archaeological site ticket (Rs 3500 in January 2016). Very interesting guided tour (free) led by an archaeologist. On the first room, a large model of the city and ruins gives an idea of how enormous the city was. Many photos of the monuments before and after restoration. Stone sculptures of Hindu deities, Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, fragments of columns and capitels. Interesting stone boxes with offerings. Dancing Shiva Nataraja in bronze. Really worth the visit (better before the ruins)

It is a fascinating museum with the reconstruction of the palaces of the rulers of Polonnaruwa and Annuradhapura, many artifacts, book shop etc. We decided to visit the museum after visiting the archeological sites mainly to avoid the hot sun. It would have helped to have simple brochures to take away to read and digest the vast information. Similarly it would also help to have information for children.
Only 5-6 rooms, but many things to help enhance your experience of visiting Polonnuruwa. Reconstructions are good.

At first glance , what appear to be rather nondescript artefacts in the initial halls of this Dutch-architect-designed and rather poorly maintained museum turns out to be fascinating insight into the history of this 11century medieval city. The recreation of the Vatadage ( An ancient Buddhist Shrine built on a series of circular stone tiers and surrounded by stone columns that probably supported an elaborate roof) and the amazing and priceless bronzes from the Chola Period were the highlights for me. The influence these buildings and art have have had on modern architecture ( the country's current Parliament, for instance) in Sri Lanka is clearly seen in this museum. I wish the 35 $ ticket charge from foreign visitors would be invested in the upkeep of the building and facilities that house this valuable collection of antiquities. The museum is the point of entry to the grounds that most of the ancient ruined (and in some instances well preserved and restored) sites are on. This is place you must visit if you have an interest in ancient art and history.

I recommend that you buy your site tickets and spend an hour looking at the reconstructions and artefacts in the museum. That way you are able to contextualise and put in historical lineage the sites and monuments. Otherwise some of them can look like a bunch of rocks to you. There a number of multi lingual guides around who will offer to take you around the sites. Make sure you speak to a couple and be comfortable with their story telling style or you might get some one who forgets the tree for the forest. As per other museums in Sri Lanka, no photography. Put your iPad/iPhone away or risk it being rudely grabbed off you. If you are a Hindu history buff, some great early bronzes are on display at the back of the museum. These artefacts would only be behind glass and rope, in other parts of the world, so take a moment and absorb their magnificence.

It is very interesting archaeological museum that give you some impressions about Polonnaruwa as former capital. It's not big and around an hour is enough for visit. It has few rooms that dedicates to different topics. Each room has very good selections of exhibits with titles in English. There are very beautiful bronze statuettes of Shiva as well. There are also many nice photos and information about Polonnaruwa archaeological sites. We enjoyed a lot models of former capital and its buildings. It helped to imagine them when we saw ruins. Museum has small shop with interesting selections of thematic books. We are really glad that we visited museum. It's really worth an hour.

You have to visit the museum in order to buy your extortionately priced tickets to the site (7,000 SLR for a European couple). We'd recommend then moving swiftly onto  the site itself (given that your ticket is only vaid for the day) and then returning to the museum later in the day when you will appreciate the air-conditioning and be able to relate some of the museum's reconstructions of what you've seen for yourself. The museum contains some amazing Shiva statues as well as further information on the archaeological ruins. The museum has a small bookshop and clean toilets (but no refreshments / cafe). Staff can be rather officious.

This is somewhere between average and very good. This museum is the best starting point for you to get some background and information about the ruins. The pity is that while there are models/recreations of parts of the site/ruins it is not easy to relate them to what you will see later in the ruined city. A standout overhead plan showing the city from above which then leads you to separate parts and recreations/visualizations of those parts would have helped me gain a greater understanding. This is still a good site and one at which you can get information to give you the background to the ruins. If you like history you should go, if you don't like history you should still go just in case this is what spurs you to become interested in the rise and fall of civilisations.
Its included in your ticket for all the sites, but was nothing special. Few bits and bots in there, but unless it's raining, spend your time outdoors at the other sights.

Very nicely organised museum with part found at the site good rebuild designs of the temples and good explanations of historical fact. Forst visit the museum to get a good idea and than go and visit the site

This could be so much better done.  At least there are some artists conceptions of what the many very extensive structures may have looked like.  Start here, be disappointed, but at least have a framework for understanding the complex..

Since your ticket only lasts for one day, and the museum could take hours, I'd skip it and head out to the temples and architecture, and if you have time, come back to the museum. Here's my argument: there are many museums in the world, but this ancient city is intricate, expansive and time-consuming to explore. Manage your time wisely!
